feature.name: Divine Domain: Chaos Domain (HB)
feature.text:
Clerics of chaos, primarily linked with the Windspeaker and Ba-Ka faiths, embrace spontaneity, freedom, and perpetual change. Their decision-making reflects this spirit, using luck and randomness to determine the optimal course of action in uncertain situations. It's not unusual for a cleric of chaos to cast lots when concrete evidence is lacking, acknowledging the futility of controlling chance and fully accepting it. These clerics maintain that unpredictability is the only constant and that excessive reliance on laws and order stifles progress. They consider hierarchy limiting, as it constrains individuals and favors those in power. They believe natural chaos enables creatures to unveil their true selves and achieve their potential through self-responsibility. Windspeaker clerics of chaos honor Tamera and Bauron, the dual deities, by accepting the unpredictable and leaving matters to chance. They assert the world was born from the fusion of these conflicting natures, creating chaos. Conversely, clerics of chaos devoted to Ba-Ka, the Spirit God of Magic, laud the deity's endorsement of magic in all its forms. They value that Chaos domain clerics can use magic from other domains, crediting this to Ba-Ka's influence. These clerics see the extensive and intricate power of magic as irrefutable evidence of chaos's potency, as magic transforms the world's structure and rules. The Evolutionist Church previously harbored clerics of chaos who considered Bauron a God of Chaos. However, recent revelations from angels exposed the Ungods' manipulation of sacred scriptures. Now recognizing Bauron as a law-abiding god of punishment, these clerics have either amended their views or left the church to pursue new life paths.
In Other Settings: Clerics in this domain associate with chaos gods like Loki and Seth. They usually seek to subvert the status quo of the world, bringing chaos and disorder and destabilizing society and the prevailing authorities. Some may seek good and innovation, while others may dedicate themselves to destruction.
Domain Spells: At each indicated cleric level, add the listed spells to your spells prepared. They do not count towards your limit.
Spells of the Chaos Domain: Cleric Level | Spell 1st | faerie fire, shadow noose 3rd | mirror image, shatter 5th l| ightning bolt, protection from energy 7th | confusion, hallucinatory terrain 9th | cloudkill, commune
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 215 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Preparing Spells (Chaos Domain (HB))
feature.text:
When you're preparing your spells, immediately after finishing a long rest, you may choose to prepare your spells using the cleric spell list, or roll 1d6 and compare the result to the Determining the List of Spells for Clerics of Chaos table to randomly determine which spell list you will use to prepare them.
Determining the List of Spells for Clerics of Chaos: d6 | Spell List 1 | Bard 2 | Cleric 3 | Druid 4 | Sorcerer 5 | Warlock 6 | Wizard
When you prepare spells from spell lists other than the cleric spell list, they become considered cleric spells for you. You retain access to all spells from your domain, but not other cleric spells. All other cleric spellcasting rules apply normally. Even if you acquire a spell list whose normal casters do not know all spells on the list to prepare them, you will still use the cleric rules, able to prepare any spell on the list as if it were a known spell for you. As a cleric of chaos, it's important to prepare a spell list for each possible option above in advance. This will ensure that you're ready to play and can easily switch your spell list as needed, without making other players wait. Remember to be courteous and considerate to your fellow players, even as you embody the chaos of your deity.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 215 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Infuse Chaos (Chaos Domain (HB))
feature.text:
Starting at 1st level, you may choose to invoke chaos while casting a spell. By doing so, you modify the spell's damage type randomly. Roll 1d10 and refer to the Infuse Chaos table to determine the new damage type. If the spell originally inflicts the same damage, the chaos-infused spell gains additional power, granting an extra 1d10 bonus damage of that same type. This bonus increases to 2d10 at 12th level.
Infuse Chaos: d10 | Damage Type 1 | Acid 2 | Bludgeoning 3 | Cold 4 | Fire 5 | Lightning 6 | Necrotic 7 | Poison 8 | Psychic 9 | Radiant 10 | Thunder
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 215 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Channel Divinity: Chaotic Presence (Chaos Domain (HB))
feature.text:
At 2nd level, you can harness your Channel Divinity to emit an aura of pure chaos, confusing hostile creatures and inciting them to strike their allies. As an action, you raise your holy symbol, forcing all enemies within 30 feet of you who can see you to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, they are compelled to move up to 10 feet towards another creature of your choosing and make a melee attack if possible. This movement does not provoke opportunity attacks, and it occurs according to the initiative order.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 215 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Irregular Destruction (Chaos Domain (HB))
feature.text:
At 6th level, you gain the power to wield chaotic energies against your foes. As an action, roll 1d8 to select an effect from the Irregular Destruction table. Then, expend a spell slot of your choosing and make a ranged spell attack against a target within 60 feet of you. A successful attack inflicts 2d8 damage per spell slot level expended, with the damage type determined by rolling 1d10 and referring to the Infuse Chaos table.
Irregular Destruction: d8 | Effect 1 | You make the attack roll with disadvantage. 2 | On a successful attack, treat all damage dice of this attack as if they rolled a 3. 3 | Consider a successful attack as a miss and a miss as a hit. 4 | Your attack targets another hostile creature within 60 feet of the original target. If there is no other creature, the target remains unchanged. 5 | On a successful attack, the creature has disadvantage on the next attack it makes until the start of your next turn. 6 | On a successful attack, the creature is frightened of you until the end of your next turn. 7 | You roll the attack roll with advantage. 8 | On a successful attack, treat all damage dice of this attack as if they rolled an 8.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 215 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Potent Spellcasting (Chaos Domain (HB))
feature.text:
Starting at the 8th level, you add your Wisdom modifier to the damage dealt by any cleric cantrip you cast.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 215 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Zone of Chaos (Chaos Domain (HB))
feature.text:
Starting at 17th level, as a bonus action, you can create an aura of chaotic energy extending 15 feet around you for a minute or until you deactivate it with a bonus action. Any hostile creature that begins its turn within the aura or enters it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or be subjected to the effects of the confusion spell. Creatures that succeed on this saving throw are immune to your aura for the next 24 hours. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier, with all uses regained after a long rest.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 215 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Divine Domain: Courage Domain (HB)
feature.text:
I n a world fraught with peril, uncertainty, and hardship, clerics are some of the selected few destined to fulfill a higher calling. To rise to this challenge, they must embody exceptional mental and moral fortitude—true valor. Considering the paramount role that courage plays in their faith, it is little wonder that numerous deities claim dominion over this domain. One of such deities, The Glorious One has many clerics dedicated to the Courage domain, inspiring their followers to persevere through formidable circumstances and combat malevolence in pursuit of a better world. The Glorious One's standard, soaring high during conflicts, emboldens others to champion the cause of righteousness and remain steadfast in the face of trepidation. Tamera, the goddess of the sun and life, also boasts some disciples who uphold the tenet of courage, for they believe in kindling hope within the disheartened. Her adherents are celebrated for their unwavering dedication to aiding the destitute and uplifting the spirits of the populace. The dwarves of Tanares hold another assemblage of intrepid clerics with utmost esteem. These clerics of Dorsi are distinguished by their dauntlessness, resoluteness, and rousing battle cries. In times of strife, they spearhead the vanguard, bolstering their comrades to achieve greatness and instilling terror within their adversaries. These valiant clerics embody the essence of warriors, brandishing their weapons with expertise and igniting courage in those who surround them. As emissaries of their divine patrons, they epitomize bravery, guiding the common folk along the path of righteousness and honor. Be it a soldier on the battlefield or an adventurer delving into the uncharted, these intrepid champions of courage are able to embolden the resolute and face any challenge head on. Steered by their unyielding spirit and celestial mandate, they will never yield, advancing toward triumph with valor in their hearts.
In Other Settings: Clerics of this domain associate with gods of courage, war, and order, such as Ares and Heimdall. They typically seek to confront dangers and achieve social peace through bravery and order.
Domain Spells: At each indicated cleric level, add the listed spells to your spells prepared. They do not count towards your limit.
Courage Domain Spells: Cleric Level | Spells 1st | heroism, shield of faith 3rd | branding smite, veil of bravery* 5th | haste, revivify 7th | freedom of movement, stoneskin 9th | greater restoration, legend lore
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 218 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Bonus Proficiencies (Courage Domain (HB))
feature.text:
At 1st level, you gain proficiency with martial weapons and heavy armor.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 219 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Words of Encouragement (Courage Domain (HB))
feature.text:
At 1st level, you have a number of Courage Points equal to your Wisdom modifier. You recover all your Courage Points after a short rest. The Courage Points can initially be used in three ways:
• When a creature within 30 feet of you fails a saving throw, you can spend a Courage Point as a reaction to instill in it the will to fight on. The creature can make a new saving throw and must use the second result.
• As a bonus action, you can spend a Courage Point to summon your inner strength and smite your foes. Until the start of your next turn, your first successful melee attack deals +1d10 damage of the same type as your weapon. This damage increases to +2d10 at 6th level, +3d10 at 12th level, and +4d10 at 18th level.
• As an action, you can spend a Courage Point to shout a powerful war cry that strengthens your party's resolve. You and all allies within 30 feet of you gain a number of temporary hit points equal to 1d6 + your cleric level for 1 minute, and can roll a saving throw to remove any effect causing the frightened condition. While the temporary hit points last, they also give advantage on all other saving throws made against effects that cause the frightened condition.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 219 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Channel Divinity: Bolster the Spirit (Courage Domain (HB))
feature.text:
Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to bolster the courage of a creature you touch. As an action, you can give the touched creature one of the following benefits:
• +1 to AC • +1 to attack rolls • +1 to all saving throws • +1 to all damage rolls This effect lasts for 1 minute.
When you use this feature, you can choose to spend a Courage Point to give a touched creature two different benefits instead of one.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 219 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Channel Divinity: Take heart (Courage Domain (HB))
feature.text:
At 6th level, if an ally within 30 feet of you drops to 0 hit points but isn't killed outright, you can use your reaction and one Courage Point to let them instead drop to 1 hit point.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 219 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Divine Strike (Courage Domain (HB))
feature.text:
At 8th level, you gain the ability to infuse your weapon attacks with divine energy. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can trigger the attack to deal an extra 1d8 radiant damage to the target. When you reach the 14th level, the bonus damage increases to 2d8.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 219 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Unyielding Spirit (Courage Domain (HB))
feature.text:
At 17th level, you and all allies within 15 feet of you become immune to the frightened condition. Additionally, you gain advantage on all Wisdom and Constitution saving throws.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 219 (Homebrew)
